para.paratext: Under Georgia law, “[i]f scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise, if: (1) The testimony is based upon sufficient facts or data; (2) The testimony is the product of reliable principles and methods; and (3) The witness has applied the principles and methods reliably to the facts of the case which have been or will be admitted into evidence before the trier of fact.”[1]

Georgia's 2005 Tort Reform Legislation, in particular the enactment of former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-67.1 (now O.C.G.A. §§ 24-7-702 and 24-7-703), split Georgia law regarding the admission of scientific evidence by applying different rules for the admission of expert testimony in civil and criminal cases. (For a full discussion of expert testimony, see Chapter 7, supra.)

When data from scientific testing or procedures is involved as evidence, it is important to be able to properly identify all samples or objects from the scene of the event to the trial. “To show a chain of custody adequate to preserve the identity of fungible evidence, the [s]tate must prove with reasonable certainty that the evidence is the same as that seized and that there has been no tampering or substitution. The [s]tate is not required to foreclose every possibility of tampering; it need only show reasonable assurance of the identity of the evidence.”[2]
Smith v. State, 291 Ga. App. 353, 354–55, 662 S.E.2d 176 (2008) (quoting Maldonado v. State, 268 Ga. App. 691, 603 S.E.2d 58 (2004)).
See also Stringer v. State, 285 Ga. App. 599, 603, 647 S.E.2d 310 (2007).
“[I]n proving chain of custody, the state is not required to show that the substance was guarded each minute it is in one's custody.” Dempsey v. State, 265 Ga. App. 175, 177, 593 S.E.2d 362 (2004).
If the article is not fungible, such as a pistol, the chain of custody need not be shown. West v. State, 146 Ga. App. 120, 245 S.E.2d 478 (1978).

See also Cobb v. State, 244 Ga. 344, 260 S.E.2d 60 (1979); Gray v. State, 151 Ga. App. 684, 261 S.E.2d 402 (1979); Harper v. State, 251 Ga. 183, 304 S.E.2d 693 (1983); Bissell v. State, 157 Ga. App. 711, 278 S.E.2d 415 (1981) (chain of custody need not be shown as to fingerprints).
In Kelly v. State, 145 Ga. App. 780, 245 S.E.2d 20 (1978), it was held that the chain of custody is not an issue at a hearing on a motion to suppress.
If no objection to the evidence is made based on the chain of custody, this is a waiver. Schauver v. State, 146 Ga. App. 701, 247 S.E.2d 228 (1978).

The chain of custody was properly shown in Blair v. State, 245 Ga. 611, 266 S.E.2d 214 (1980); Groves v. State, 152 Ga. App. 606, 263 S.E.2d 501 (1979); Williams v. State, 153 Ga. App. 421, 265 S.E.2d 341 (1980).

See also Schlanger v. State, 290 Ga. App. 407, 659 S.E.2d 823 (2008) (state established unbroken chain of custody for blood sample: the technician who drew defendant's blood, the arresting officer, and the forensic toxicologist each testified, describing the manner in which they handled, labeled, and transferred the evidence).
